pros: FSGV has a wealth of long-time staff with demonstrated skill and expertise in their chosen fields. Staff teams are recognized for their excellence in every service area across dozens of very different programs. Teams have built strong connections and community within themselves, and many staff are additionally engaged at an agency level, and with community tables and groups. review_title: Lack of funding can mean lack of competence
pros:
Meaningful work.

Salaries are low but on par with similar organizations.

If you’re in a department with good managers and staff it’s great but if you’re not, it can be really bad.

Can be a good foot-in-the-door for young people if they can tough it out and plan to move on to keep up their spirits.
cons:
Lack of funding leads to lack of oversight and competence by HR staff and Managers, because quality employees are hard to find at the wages offered. 

This has led to several issues including 
-vacant positions and self management within department
-aggressive or popular staff gaining too much influence and bullying 
-positive employees leaving because of toxic environments
-poor knowledge and poor best practices
-high turnover at most levels.

Frontline worker conditions can be exploitative and almost no opportunities to move to a higher position. Not conducive to long-term employment for most.

cons: I'm not sure this is a con but the agency is in a period of change.  As humans, change is all we can expect to grow.  Change is always scary but it can be exciting as well.
